snippet.textDisplay:
So I'm rebuilding my old PC from back in 2013 (basically just reusing the case and power supply) I had some success just replacing the old GPU with an rx590. I know Nvidia has better GPUs but at the time it seemed to be a good fit for my old motherboard and Im really happy with it so far. Now that I've got some cash coming from my tax refund its time to upgrade the rest. I've done a little research and came up with this.
MB - msi b450max (went with the max for the expanded BIOS memory and Ryzen 2 BIOS out of the box)
CPU - ryzen 3600x (I know I'm just paying more for the X but I'm new to overclocking and figured the preset OC would be better till I know what Im doing)
RAM - Corsair VENGEANCE LPX 16GB (2 x 8GB)
SSD - Seagate Barracuda 120 SSD 500GB SATA 6GB/S
HDD - Seagate BarraCuda 2TB HDD SATA 6Gb/s 7200 RPM 256MB Cache ( Just because my old HDD is on its last leg and the seagate is only $50 which puts me over the mark to get 18 month financing on Amazon)
I still need to check compatibility on all the parts but I'm 90% sure that will all work out. So this being my frist real PC build I wanted to ask if anyone thinks this is a good build, or if they see any problems with it? Try to keep in mind I already have an RX590 GPU and am sticking with that for the foreseeable future. I use Relive to stream it to my Oculus Quest and have not had any real problems with dropouts and I only really need to hit 72 FPS with it. VR is my main goal with this build, but I do some normal gaming too and already know most games will have to be on low settings. Thanks in advance for any help you might offer.
snippet.textOriginal:
So I'm rebuilding my old PC from back in 2013 (basically just reusing the case and power supply) I had some success just replacing the old GPU with an rx590. I know Nvidia has better GPUs but at the time it seemed to be a good fit for my old motherboard and Im really happy with it so far. Now that I've got some cash coming from my tax refund its time to upgrade the rest. I've done a little research and came up with this.
MB -  msi b450max (went with the max for the expanded BIOS memory and Ryzen 2 BIOS out of the box)
CPU - ryzen 3600x   (I know I'm just paying more for the X but I'm new to overclocking and figured the preset OC would be better till I know what Im doing)
RAM - Corsair VENGEANCE LPX 16GB (2 x 8GB)
SSD - Seagate Barracuda 120 SSD 500GB SATA 6GB/S
HDD - Seagate BarraCuda 2TB HDD SATA 6Gb/s 7200 RPM 256MB Cache ( Just because my old HDD is on its last leg and the seagate is only $50 which puts me over the mark to get 18 month financing on Amazon)
I still need to check compatibility on all the parts but I'm 90% sure that will all work out. So this being my frist real PC build I wanted to ask if anyone thinks this is a good build, or if they see any problems with it? Try to keep in mind I already have an RX590 GPU and am sticking with that for the foreseeable future.  I use Relive to stream it to my Oculus Quest and have not had any real problems with dropouts and I only really need to hit 72 FPS with it. VR is my main goal with this build, but I do some normal gaming too and already know most games will have to be on low settings. Thanks in advance for any help you might offer.

snippet.textDisplay:
If you plan on going wireless here are a few things you need to know.


The battery that comes with it lasts about 3 hours and take way to long to recharge imo. Still if you only play a few hours a day that will work.
It's advised that you buy a third party battery on at least 20 000 mAh. This will give you more hours and they are often quicker to charge up. It needs to be a Quick Charge 3.0 type too. If you're in Sweden or countries nearby you can buy the Andersson Powerbank 20.000 and it will work just fine. Good price too.


There is a broadcast thing that you need to put up somewhere so that it can communicate with the wireless device. This device does not like when it can't see the device so if you have it on one spot, your back needs to be towards that spot for best enjoyment.


There is a setting that makes controllers shut off after 5 minutes when inactive but apparently it kicks in anyway. So turn it off.


But I'm enjoying the wireless feature so much. I don't feel any problems with it either which is impressive and I'm using the normal HTC Vive.
snippet.textOriginal:

The battery that comes with it lasts about 3 hours and take way to long to recharge imo. Still if you only play a few hours a day that will work.
It's advised that you buy a third party battery on at least 20 000 mAh. This will give you more hours and they are often quicker to charge up. It needs to be a Quick Charge 3.0 type too. If you're in Sweden or countries nearby you can buy the Andersson Powerbank 20.000 and it will work just fine. Good price too.


There is a broadcast thing that you need to put up somewhere so that it can communicate with the wireless device. This device does not like when it can't see the device so if you have it on one spot, your back needs to be towards that spot for best enjoyment.


There is a setting that makes controllers shut off after 5 minutes when inactive but apparently it kicks in anyway. So turn it off.


But I'm enjoying the wireless feature so much. I don't feel any problems with it either which is impressive and I'm using the normal HTC Vive.

snippet.textDisplay: I would really like to see more laptops, especially no compromises laptops, especially especially thin and light no compromises. Maybe a video trying to find most power per volume (and maybe build quality). I'm a gamedev, but I don't like to sit in one place day in and day out so I want a laptop that is more powerful than the average gamers desktop but still thin enough to slip into an already overcrowded bag. I know it's a very personal reason but I can't be the only one who wants (or needs) a laptop like that among these 10 million people.
snippet.textOriginal: I would really like to see more laptops, especially no compromises laptops, especially _especially_ *thin and light* no compromises. Maybe a video trying to find most power per volume (and maybe build quality). I'm a gamedev, but I don't like to sit in one place day in and day out so I want a laptop that is more powerful than the average gamers desktop but still thin enough to slip into an already overcrowded bag. I know it's a very personal reason but I can't be the only one who wants (or needs) a laptop like that among these 10 million people.

snippet.textDisplay: My answer to this question is 0$. I have been an early adopter of VR and trust me when I say this, don't spend a dime on it. This game alone can't justify the upgrade or even buying a headset alone assuming that's all you need. In case your wondering I don't have motion sickness and never have I can play for 10 hours strait without using teleport locomotion without any issues whatsoever (and apparently very few ppl are that lucky). The problem is VR gets old very fast and you will eventually let the HDM collect dust because it's simply annoying to have on your head at all times and you will end up playing your games on your good old monitor.
snippet.textOriginal: My answer to this question is 0$. I have been an early adopter of VR and trust me when I say this, don't spend a dime on it. In case your wondering I don't have motion sickness and never have I can play for 10 hours strait without using teleport locomotion without any issues whatsoever (and apparently very few ppl are that lucky). snippet.textDisplay:
4:47 you can solve this easily with some straps for your controllers. I use AMVR grips, they're reasonably cheap and work very well for me. Makes the controller a bit bulkier (which is nice with my somewhat large hands) and after adjusting everything I can just slide my hand in and it holds on well enough without further adjusting.


The fact that I'm running the bare minimum of what you're testing here does really drive the point home that I should upgrade my videocard already :P but I'm still kind of hoping to hold out until the next generation of Nvidia cards...


Also I don't get why you're dumping on using a Quest wirelessly... I've played plenty of games streaming over wifi using VR Desktop and it's great. I even got beat saber playable by fiddling with the latency settings, although it's obviously MUCH better to play the native quest version. It also never disconnects, unlike your USB connection apparently.
snippet.textOriginal:
4:47 you can solve this easily with some straps for your controllers. I use AMVR grips, they're reasonably cheap and work very well for me. Makes the controller a bit bulkier (which is nice with my somewhat large hands) and after adjusting everything I can just slide my hand in and it holds on well enough without further adjusting.


The fact that I'm running the bare minimum of what you're testing here does really drive the point home that I should upgrade my videocard already :P but I'm still kind of hoping to hold out until the next generation of Nvidia cards...


Also I don't get why you're dumping on using a Quest wirelessly... I've played plenty of games streaming over wifi using VR Desktop and it's great. I even got beat saber playable by fiddling with the latency settings, although it's obviously MUCH better to play the native quest version. It also never disconnects, unlike your USB connection apparently.

snippet.textDisplay: CoD Warzone uses over 1.5GB/s on my M.2 drive, so YES there is a tangible performance gain in gaming with a better SSD let alone SSD over HDD. I dont get frame freezes, my teammates on Sata SSDs all have freezes and crashes (2 are running it off their ssd, other 2 are running off HDDs with their OS on an SSD).
snippet.textOriginal: CoD Warzone uses over 1.5GB/s on my M.2 drive, so YES there is a tangible performance gain in gaming with a better SSD let alone SSD over HDD. I dont get frame freezes, my teammates on Sata SSDs all have freezes and crashes (2 are running it off their ssd, other 2 are running off HDDs with their OS on an SSD).

snippet.textDisplay: I think it might be time to start using Windows Mixed Reality headsets such as the Odyssey Plus. The O+ has a great 90hz refresh rate and excellent display. The tracking has definitely improved as well. I actually prefer the colors and lenses of the O+ to my newer Index. The Index god rays can be quite distracting at times.
snippet.textOriginal: I think it might be time to start using Windows Mixed Reality headsets such as the Odyssey Plus. The O+ has a great 90hz refresh rate and excellent display. The tracking has definitely improved as well. I actually prefer the colors and lenses of the O+ to my newer Index. The Index god rays can be quite distracting at times.

snippet.textDisplay:
Certainly not worth spending $500-1000 for VR for it alone.



 People are raving over the game simply because it is Half Life and highly anticipated. But, look at the game as a whole objectively...other than VR, it literally just a game in the Half Life world. There is little that's innovative about it or the VR used.

Certainly not worth spending $500-1000 for VR for it alone. 



 People are raving over the game simply because it is Half Life and highly anticipated. But, look at the game as a whole objectively...other than VR, it literally just a game in the Half Life world. There is little that's innovative about it or the VR used.

snippet.textDisplay:
03:30: That's because Oculus is a bit of a one-way thing: Yes, they are pretty much the only other source of "big" VR games right now, but those officially only run on Oculus hardware. Also, while they do provide an Oculus SDK, they don't give a rat's ass about supporting anything but their own stuff. Yes, ReVive exists and makes this less of an issue, but it clearly shows the mindset of Facebook about this whole thing.
I'm not saying Valve are self-less angels, but at least when it comes to SteamVR and pushing VR, they've been pretty awesome overall.
09:30 If you're looking for a difference in shadow quality, don't look at baked shadows? I would have assumed that that is pretty basic knowledge for a tech YouTuber. You could also check the advanced performance settings in the game to see what you're actually changing. That said: The game already looks pretty great for a VR game, even at low settings and the higher settings mostly affect some atmospheric effects etc.
13:40 wrong comparison picture, as others said, but on top of that: This really shows how strong nostalgia can be. Also, don't use "realistically" when your only point of comparison is an obviously very rose-tinted memory. Go and have a look at HL2 again.
13:50 There are plenty of scenes without fog and nice vistas. The fog here is a stylistic choice.
17:30 A full Vive Pro kit is officially still at $1460, roughly $400 more expensive than a full Index kit. Its resolution is identical, the refresh rate is lower. Meh? Yes, the wireless kit for an additional $470 will probably make it more immersive, but then you're at almost $2000 for the VR kit. I mean, I really, really like VR, but that's too steep for me.

I use a GTX 1080 and run Alyx with ultra settings except for shadows and, I think, one other setting at high. Works perfectly fine using an Index at 120 Hz. I'm not sure if I'm always at a rock solid 120 FPS, but the current motion smoothing in SteamVR works well enough to make it feel like I am.
snippet.textOriginal:
03:30: That's because Oculus is a bit of a one-way thing: Yes, they are pretty much the only other source of "big" VR games right now, but those officially only run on Oculus hardware. Also, while they do provide an Oculus SDK, they don't give a rat's ass about supporting anything but their own stuff. Yes, ReVive exists and makes this less of an issue, but it clearly shows the mindset of Facebook about this whole thing. 
I'm not saying Valve are self-less angels, but at least when it comes to SteamVR and pushing VR, they've been pretty awesome overall.
09:30 If you're looking for a difference in shadow quality, don't look at baked shadows? I would have assumed that that is pretty basic knowledge for a tech YouTuber. You could also check the advanced performance settings in the game to see what you're actually changing. That said: The game already looks pretty great for a VR game, even at low settings and the higher settings mostly affect some atmospheric effects etc.
13:40 wrong comparison picture, as others said, but on top of that: This really shows how strong nostalgia can be. Also, don't use "realistically" when your only point of comparison is an obviously very rose-tinted memory. Go and have a look at HL2 again.
13:50 There are plenty of scenes without fog and nice vistas. The fog here is a stylistic choice.
17:30 A full Vive Pro kit is officially still at $1460, roughly $400 more expensive than a full Index kit. Its resolution is identical, the refresh rate is lower. Meh? Yes, the wireless kit for an additional $470 will probably make it more immersive, but then you're at almost $2000 for the VR kit. I mean, I really, really like VR, but that's too steep for me.

I use a GTX 1080 and run Alyx with ultra settings except for shadows and, I think, one other setting at high. Works perfectly fine using an Index at 120 Hz. I'm not sure if I'm always at a rock solid 120 FPS, but the current motion smoothing in SteamVR works well enough to make it feel like I am.
